title: Bill Belichick explains ‘simple’ reason why he decided to ban Patriots scout at UNC
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick banned a Patriots scout from UNC practices, citing tensions with the Patriots as the reason.
Patriots head coach Mike Vrabel acknowledged UNC's decision and emphasized focusing on other scouting methods.
The decision follows Belichick's strained relationship with the Patriots and owner Robert Kraft since his departure in 2023.

title: Raiders 14, Patriots 10 (3rd): Vegas capitalizes off Maye INT
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Raiders lead the Patriots 14-10 in the third quarter after Ashton Jeanty's first career touchdown.
Drake Maye's interception sets up a 56-yard scoring drive for the Raiders, led by Isaiah Pola-Mao's pick.
Patriots' defense and offense show improvement after halftime, leading 10-7 before a second-half slump.

title: Watch: Dropkick Murphys blast Trump, but stump for a longshot New England candidate
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Dropkick Murphys frontman Ken Casey criticized Trump during their set at the Seisiun festival in Boston.
Casey endorsed Graham Platner, a Maine veteran and oyster farmer, challenging GOP Sen. Susan Collins.
Platner aims to combat Trumpism and challenge the Democratic establishment with fresh perspectives.

title: Tenants move into first downtown apartment in Wu’s office-residential conversion program
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: The first completed apartment conversion under Mayor Wu's program is at 281 Franklin St., featuring 15 new units.
The project converted five office floors into apartments, backed by a $15 million state funding extension in June 2024.
Mayor Wu's program, addressing high office vacancy, aims to convert 700,000 sq. ft. of offices into over 800 units.

title: Disciplinary cases tripled at Harvard due to pro-Palestine protests, student newspaper reports
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Harvard disciplinary cases tripled during 2023-2024 due to pro-Palestine protests, per The Harvard Crimson.
58 students were put on probation after participating in a November 2023 occupation and April 2024 encampment.
Suspensions for five students were downgraded to probation after criticism of Harvard's disciplinary actions.

title: Photos: Music, Guinness, and lots of rain at Day 1 of Seisiún Irish music festival in Boston
author: Boston.com
bullets: The inaugural Seisiún Irish music festival faced rain delays but continued with performances at Suffolk Downs in Boston.
Highlighted acts included the Dropkick Murphys, The Hold Steady, The Scratch, The Rumjacks, and Holy Locust.
Festival-goers endured severe weather, with ponchos on sale and attendees briefly evacuated due to incoming storms.

title: Fear and Loathing in New England
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: Ralph Steadman's retrospective exhibit, 'And Another Thing,' is on display at Bates College Museum of Art in Lewiston, Maine.
In a 1970 incident, Steadman and Hunter S. Thompson attempted to vandalize a yacht while on psilocybin in Newport, Rhode Island.
The exhibit features 149 original artworks spanning Steadman's 60-year career, including collaborations with Hunter S. Thompson.

title: New report outlines how many people might lose SNAP in Greater Boston under Trump bill
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Around 40,000 adults in Greater Boston risk losing SNAP benefits under Trump's One Big Beautiful Bill, affecting 7% of recipients.
The Trump administration's bill may strip SNAP eligibility from about 9,600 legally present immigrants in Massachusetts.
Massachusetts must now cover 75% of SNAP administrative costs, resulting in a $58 million increase for fiscal year 2025.

title: 3 takeaways from the Revolution’s 3-2 loss vs. the Chicago Fire
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: New England Revolution's playoff chances are nearly over after a 3-2 loss to the Chicago Fire.
Chicago's quick early goals left New England unable to recover despite late efforts from Peyton Miller and Carles Gil.
Coach Caleb Porter took responsibility for the loss, acknowledging slimmer playoff hopes with five games remaining.

title: Boston’s preliminary election is almost here. Here’s who will be on the ballot
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston's preliminary election on Sept. 9 will narrow the field for mayoral and city council races.
Michelle Wu, Josh Kraft, Robert Cappucci, and Domingos DaRosa lead the mayoral candidates.
Ten candidates vie for four at-large city councilor positions, with eight advancing to the general election.
